Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story: I stared at the spreadsheet on my screen, the clock ticking closer to the end of the workday. As a colleague, I knew my part of the project was due today—if I missed the deadline, the next person in line would be stuck waiting, and the whole team’s timeline would unravel. My phone buzzed with a reminder: update the research logs for the latest experiment. As a scientist, I felt the weight of responsibility to document every detail accurately, even if the logs could technically wait until tomorrow. But if I rushed through the data entry now, I risked missing something important. My mind spun with the pressure—my teammate counting on me to finish, my own standards demanding careful, thorough records. I could feel the tension in my shoulders, torn between letting someone down and compromising my scientific integrity. I hovered over the keyboard, caught in the middle, unsure which role to serve first.
